Award.AwardTitle: G8 Initiative: Material Efficiency: A First Step Toward Sustainable Manufacturing of Composite Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award to the University of Southern California funds U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by the G8 Research Councils Initiative "Interdisciplinary Program on Material Efficiency - A first step towards sustainable manufacturing". This is a pilot collaboration among the U.S. National Science Foundation, the Canadian National Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC), the French Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR), the German Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR),and the United Kingdom Research Councils (RCUK), supporting collaborative research projects selected on a competitive basis that are comprised of researchers from at least three of the partner countries.

Composite parts for aerospace structures are presently manufactured using autoclaves, large heated pressure vessels used to cure laminates consisting of fiber layers partly impregnated with polymer films, called prepregs. Autoclaves are highly effective in producing high-performance laminates with high fiber loadings and low defect content, but they consume large amounts of energy and nitrogen gas. A new class of vacuum bag only (VBO) prepregs was recently introduced to eliminate the need for autoclaves during manufacture. Work at the composite centers at the University of Southern California (USC) and McGill University has begun to develop fundamental understanding of processes inherent to VBO prepreg processing, suggesting the broad utility of this new class of materials. While these developments have great potential for expanding the use of composite materials and VBO prepregs in particular, key technical challenges must be addressed to realize widespread acceptance and use.

This interdisciplinary project with the United States, Canada, Germany and the United Kingdom focuses on (1) developing fundamental understanding of the effects of manufacturing process parameters on defects in composites produced with VBO prepregs, (2) improving material efficiency by reducing material waste in the automated manufacture of composite parts, (3) accelerating insertion of VBO materials technology through simulation and validation of VBO composite performance, and (4) improving sustainability by advancing recycling technology and developing and demonstrating energy-efficient smart tooling concepts. These objectives require an approach that combines expertise in process simulation, automated manufacturing, materials qualification and acceptance, and fundamental polymer science and technology.

The proposed work will leverage the expertise of researchers at major academic composite centers in four G8 countries. Project personnel will be trained in state-of-the art tools for design, manufacture and re-use of next-generation composites. Postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students will be involved in the completion of this work. The project will involve participating students and early-career researchers in a coordinated effort to address scientific issues of global importance through international collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Composites are engineered, multi-constituent materials that offer better properties-to-weight ratios, durability and design versatility over traditional metals. These characteristics allow the production of strong, stiff, lightweight structures that can improve performance, increase safety and enable new functionalities. Currently, composites are enabling more fuel-efficient and safer aircraft, large-scale wind turbines for alternative energy generation, novel spacecraft, medical prosthetics such as artificial limbs, and high-performance consumer goods. They are also emerging as lightweight materials for the production of fuel-efficient cars, and for natural gas storage tanks. In general, composites benefit society by allowing higher performance structures to be produced in a variety of applications and sectors of engineering.

Traditionally, composites are manufactured within large heated pressure vessels known as autoclaves. However, autoclave processing is complex, expensive, inefficient and environmentally-unfriendly. To address these issues, this project brought together research groups from the University of Southern California, in the United States, as well as from McGill University in Canada, the University of Bristol in the United Kingdom, and the Technical University Munich in Germany. The collaboration aimed to use fundamental science and applied engineering to improve the technical maturity, efficiency and sustainability of composites manufacturing methods, particularly for an emerging class of out-of-autoclave processes. The fundamental physics and chemistry of out-of-autoclave cure were studied to formulate defect reduction strategies that reduce part rejection on the basis of major microstructural flaws. Process models were created using mathematical equations and engineering theories to understand complex interactions during cure, and identify material and process characteristics leading to high quality parts. The reuse and recycling of in-process waste was studied, and feasible strategies for converting scrap material into value-added parts were demonstrated. Advanced technologies, including heated tools and in-situ process diagnostic sensing methods, were investigated in order to enable faster and more energy-efficient curing environments. Finally, data and technologies allowing faster insertion of new materials into service were developed throughout.

The project made a substantial contributions to fundamental processing science and the community's understanding of out-of-autoclave manufacturing of composites. Moreover, it led to the development of technologies that reduce part rejection rates, decrease energy consumption during cure, and can enable the upcycling of manufacturing waste. Finally, the project fostered constructive, synergistic and ongoing collaborations between academic research groups in four countries, established relationships between academia and industrial stakeholders, and led to the development of highly-qualified personnel (including graduate and undergraduate students and postdoctoral scholars).

The broader impact of the project is associated with its contribution to manufacturing efficiency of composites. The continued and growing use of composites depends largely on the ability to manufacture parts faster, less expensively, and with lower environmental impact over their life cycle. By addressing these issues using fundamental and applied research, the project contributed to the competitiveness of composite materials, and supported their continued benefits in several aspects of industry and society.
